There has always been greater difficulty in obtaining, under any government, some form of government welfare assistance for the self-employed than there has been for the wage and salary earners. The system was obviously designed for the wage and salary earner and, in my opinion, has always been administered with a bias against the self-employed.

I will give examples of several ways in which it is now harder than ever for the self-employed to receive the income security net arrangement which is available for other Australians. I refer to the unemployment benefit. Over the last few months we have been advised that it is now almost impossible for a self -employed person to get unemployment benefit because of an Administrative Appeals Tribunal determination. I put this point to the Minister and I would like to receive an answer. Is that advice correct? Is that assertion correct? It appears to be correct because of the complaints coming into my office in the electorate from the self-employed who have tried to get unemployment benefit. If this Tribunal's determination does provide some impediment surely it is up to the Government, if it is a sincere believer in providing the same or anywhere near the same level of income security for the self-employed, to do something about it.

The self-employed have always found it harder to obtain unemployment benefit because of the different income test that is used for the self-employed, which is based on annual net income or corrected income, than for the wage and salary earner, who is on a weekly income. I will give an example of the absurd situation that this creates in my electorate which is the major dairying electorate in Australia. Many a dairy farmer, whose net income is under $8,000 per annum, is available for work but is not eligible for any unemployment benefit because that figure is above the annual income level he is allowed. If the $8,000 is not the correct figure at the moment it is not far from it. It depends on the number of dependent children. Such a dairy farmer is income tested out of any assistance whatsoever; yet a tanker driver, employed by a dairy factory in the same dairy industry in the same electorate, who is earning an income, salary or wage of over $15,000 a year but is laid off for a few weeks in the off-season, is immediately eligible for a full unemployment benefit. Does the Government call that fair? Does the Government call that equitable for the unemployed in this country?

A few years ago we had the equally absurd situation that one of the criteria for the payment of sickness benefit was that one must show loss of income. I think this still applies; I have not checked it lately. Farmers who showed a negative income in the rural depression of the mid-1970s-in other words they had a minus cash flow-were not eligible for sickness benefit. How could one have a loss of income if one did not have any income? That was the absurd logic that applied at one stage. To my knowledge that was corrected by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. I hope that is still the case. If it is not the case I would be pleased to be advised.

The final point concerning this question of income security for the self- employed relates to the asset test. I believe that the abolition of the asset test by the coalition Government in 1976 was a great social welfare reform. For years we had fought for its abolition. This was one of the recommendations of the Henderson Commission of Inquiry into Poverty. New Zealand had never had an asset test; it had always had an income test and, to my knowledge, it still has only an income test. A particular problem with the self-employed is a high ratio of assets to cash flow. In fact, one of the reasons for the Australian farmer's leading position in the world in relation to efficiency is this high capital per worker. In other words, on world efficiency ratings, the more capital a worker has the more efficient he is. The Australian farmer is at the peak in capital per worker. Even for a small farm one would need about a quarter of a million dollars of assets. I would say that, in seven years out of 10, there is no way in which farmers in my area could earn $25,000 net income or get 10 per cent return on capital. Yet they will be ruled out.

It is my understanding, from answers to questions on notice in this place and in the Senate that, the farm home is exempted from the assets test if the farmer , who is applying for the pension is still living in it. Of course, he has to be 65 years of age before he is eligible for the age pension. Who else in Australia is still working at the age of 65? That is an equally absurd situation. If he is not working that farm, if he has retired and somebody else is living in that home and maintaining the farm, the farm home is included in the asset test and is used against him. In other words, this Government, by reintroducing the asset test, is doing more to destroy the family farm than any other single thing that has ever been done in this country. The younger generation must be able to live in farm homes and to work farms to allow the transfer of family farms from one generation to the next. The asset test will do more to destroy the concept of the family farm than anything else that has ever been introduced. I hope that honourable members opposite are aware of that. Some special provision has to be made to exempt the family farm home from the asset test.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few points about the rather emotive comments made by the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd).
—Sincere comments.

—The honourable member for Gippsland says that they were sincere comments. I doubt that. As the honourable member for Murray well knows, there has been no legislation at all that deals with the defined and final procedures for the assets test applicable to pensions.
—Mr Chairman, I take a point of order. What I said was based on answers to questions on notice in the Senate by the Minister for Social Security.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I repeat that the honourable member for Murray knows full well that final details of those assets tests have yet to be announced. He is engaging in an unnecessary campaign of fear and scaremongering. That is typical of the tactics of the National and Liberal parties. It is typical of their policies in Government continually to divide the community. One would think that honourable members opposite would have learnt from events on 5 March. They have not. The former Government divided the community time and time again. The object of its tactics in government was to create division. It is still doing it. I thought that honourable members opposite might have learnt something from their massive defeat on 5 March.

SPEECH.PARA: Unlike the members of the Opposition, I would like to speak to something positive in the appropriations for the Department of Health, the Department of Social Security and the Department of Veterans' Affairs. Firstly, in the area of health, I refer to the Budget allocation of $489,000 under the national disease control program. That money is allocated to control the spread of Australian encephalitis and dengue fever. The Budget increase is a very significant one. It provides for an increase of $295,000 over funding for disease control of that kind in 1982-83. Most significantly-I hope that this is of interest to the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Fisher) and the honourable member for Murray- the Commonwealth will be providing dollar for dollar a $103,000 grant to Victoria this year. As honourable members know-the honourable member for Mallee knows this full well-that compares with the very meagre, in fact miserly, $35, 000 which was actually spent by the Federal Government in Victoria in 1982-83. Of course, last August, when that decision was announced by the Federal Government, I was a candidate for Bendigo. I campaigned strongly against the then Government for that massive cut in funds for this very important activity.

I do not need to remind honourable members of the events of 1974, when 13 Australian lives were lost because of the outbreak of encephalitis. Apart from generating very serious personal and health costs for those individuals and their families, it decimated the tourist industry along the Murray and the tourist industry in my electorate of Bendigo, which area is frequently used as a thoroughfare to the Murray and as an overnight stay. I draw to the attention of honourable members, in particular the honourable member for Mallee and the honourable member for Murray, that this Budget increase is a significant one. It will enable the continuation of full and thorough research into Australian encephalitis. It should severely restrict, if not totally eliminate, further possibilities of another disastrous outbreak of Australian encephalitis.

Also in the health field I raise a matter of some concern to me and to constituents in my electorate concerning allocations made to the National Acoustic Laboratories, which come under the Department of Health. The Laboratories provide a diagnostic and remedial service to hearing impaired persons. In Victoria that service is operated from Melbourne. While I certainly acknowledge the very dedicated, sincere and conscientious efforts of all staff at the National Acoustic Laboratories to provide the best possible service, the service provided to the people of my electorate is, because of the shortage of resources, totally inadequate. Since March of this year I have received an enormous number of representations from constituents and organisations within my electorate concerning this matter. They have all complained that the National Acoustic Laboratories, visiting service to Bendigo is now less frequent than it has been in the past. The technician who used to make those visits no longer goes to Bendigo.

I want to outline briefly the extent of the need for services of this type in Bendigo. The need cannot be underestimated. I think it is important for honourable members to be aware of it. The Eaglehawk and Long Gully Community Health Centre, a magnificent complex which was funded and constructed under the previous Whitlam Government, has some seven resident general practitioners. During 1982 each of those GPs consulted, on average, 12 seriously hearing impaired persons. I have made a few investigations of my own and I think that that is a consistent level of consultation. Some 40 GPs operate in private practice throughout Bendigo. On that basis alone some 480 individuals in my electorate of Bendigo are consistently seeking services for their hearing impairments.

A second group of people need this service. I refer to the McDonald House School for Deaf Children in Bendigo. That school has 29 students. It is highly regarded by the community and performs an absolutely essential and valuable service. All the children there have very severe hearing impairments with ongoing needs for assessment and technical assistance. The third group of my constituents that needs hearing services comprises the aged. I refer particularly to the Bendigo Home and Hospital for the Aged which accommodates approximately 400 people in nursing beds. At present the home forwards more than 100 hearing aids to the National Acoustic Laboratories in Melbourne annually for repair or modification. It is making new applications at the rate of more than 12 per year.

The figures-I think they fairly and reasonably represent individual groups within my electorate-show that, in the general community, there are some 480 people with severe or serious hearing impairments who need that service. At McDonald House 29 children regularly need that service. At the Bendigo Home and Hospital for the Aged more than 100 people regularly need and require the services of the National Acoustic Laboratories. Those figures come to a total of more than 600 people. I will be raising this matter with the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) this week. I have prepared a very detailed submission to give him on the need for increased servicing in my electorate of Bendigo. I certainly hope that my comments today ensure that the Minister will be able to see fit next year when we are discussing these estimates to make an allocation for the establishment of the National Acoustic Laboratories service in Bendigo. I know that would be welcomed by the people of Bendigo, that it would be cost effective and certainly that the need is there.

The last point I make refers to aged care which again comes under the Department of Health, the Department of Social Security and, as well, initiatives taken in the Department of Veterans' Affairs. We announced in the Budget a number of new initiatives in the aged care field. Some $2m was allocated for the development of effective approaches to assessing the care and needs of aged people. It has certainly been demonstrated that aged people are happiest and best cared for when they receive the level of care which is most appropriate to their needs. That sum of money which has been allocated will enable effective assessment of aged care needs in the future and that, in turn, will ensure that premature dependency, which is sometimes created at the moment when people are put into nursing home beds when they do not need them, is eliminated in the future.

I particularly welcome those initiatives. Honourable members would be aware of the difficulties in my electorate in respect of the Stella Anderson wing of the Home and Hospital for the Aged. I have raised this matter in this Parliament in a question addressed to the Minister for Health. It is a building well ahead of its time which wants to offer care for the frail aged in the space between the care offered by hostels and nursing homes. But at the moment, as we follow the policies of the previous Government, there is simply no legislative mechanism to allow that building to be funded. As a consequence it has been unoccupied but I know that we are taking the right steps now to ensure that it can be opened.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the Sydney Town Hall last week-last Tuesday to be precise-2,500 pensioners loudly and clearly told the Hawke socialist Government what they thought of this Government's disgraceful betrayal of the pensioners of Australia since it came to power on 5 March this year. Those 2,500 very angry pensioners in the Sydney Town Hall were speaking on behalf of two million Australian pensioners who have now been hit five times in seven months by the Hawke socialist Government which publicly claims that it really cares for the pensioners, the superannuitants and the elderly citizens of Australia. The Minister for Social Security, Senator Grimes, was guest speaker at the Sydney Town Hall. It was the Minister's birthday. I suggest that it was a birthday he will never forget. The headlines tell it all. The headline in the Telegraph read : 'Pensioners rage at asset test'. The article started:

SPEECH.PARA: Grey power hit Sydney yesterday and its first victim was the Federal Social Security Minister, Senator Grimes.
The Sydney Morning Herald, in an interesting play on words, proclaimed:
Age catches up with Grimes.

Right around Australia the newspapers told the story of how 2,500 representative Australian pensioners made it very clear to the Hawke socialist Government how they felt about the Government's treatment of them-the pensioners, the elderly and the senior citizens of Australia-since the Hawke Government came to power earlier this year. Let us take our minds back to that gala theatrical performance in the Sydney Opera House earlier this year when the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) solemnly promised the pensioners and the people of Australia that a Labor government would not-these are his precise words-'take money out of the pensioners' pockets'. That was the solemn promise, the solemn pledge-a Labor government would not 'take money out of the pensioners' pockets'. I suggest that on the basis of that promise alone many thousands of pensioners right around Australia would have been conned into placing their trust in the Prime Minister and an Australian Labor Party Federal government. That trust has been sadly misplaced because in five savage blows the Hawke socialist Government has belted the pensioners of Australia over the head. I suggest that it has treated them disgracefully and unjustly and that it will reap a massive electoral backlash from the senior citizens of Australia, who call themselves grey power, at the next Federal election.

In chronological order the five savage blows are as follows: First, the reintroduction of means testing of the over 70-year-old pensioners for which there was no mandate whatsoever and not a word of which was spoken in the policy speech; secondly, the lump sum superannuation tax proposals; thirdly, the freezing of the tax threshold; fourthly, the proposed asset means testing; and, fifthly, the Medicare mugging, to use the words of the shadow Minister for Health, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), or, in my words, the Medicare rip-off, whereby single pensioners will be robbed of $2.30 a week and married pensioners will be robbed of $3.90 a week from May of 1984. I want to address some remarks to these five savage blows delivered to the pensioners, the elderly, the aged, the infirm and the widows of Australia by this Hawke socialist Government which has the hypocrisy to claim that it is a caring government. Let us take them one by one.

The reintroduction of means testing of pensions for over 70-year-olds is a cruel, unjust and inequitable move by the Hawke Government and reverses a just and humane action by the Whitlam Government. Let it be conceded on both sides of this chamber that it was Prime Minister Whitlam who had the courage to stand in this Parliament and say that it is unjust, inequitable and unfair to means test the over 70-year-olds of Australia. He said that his Government believed that it was so unjust that it should be repealed. In 1974 the Whitlam Government, to its very great credit, brought into this Parliament legislation which abolished means testing of the over 70-year-olds. Mr Whitlam, again to his credit, said: ' We will move as economic circumstances permit to reduce the age further'. In other words, it was not a one-off commitment. It was a commitment put into practice with a further commitment to move down the line. But in 1983 the Hawke socialist Government has trampled on and swept aside that just and humane action carried out by the former Labor Government under the Prime Ministership of Mr Whitlam.

The second blow was the lump sum superannuation tax proposals which are putting fear and concern into the hearts of the senior citizens of Australia. It is unjust and iniquitous to move from a tax on 5 per cent of the lump sum to a tax of 30 per cent up to 46 per cent. What does this do for all those hundreds and thousands of Australian citizens who have believed all their lives that it is right and proper to be prudent and to prepare for their retirements? They now find that as the result of the actions of this Government they will not have the money upon which to retire and live in some moderate standard of comfort. They will not have assets to pass on, as they are properly entitled to, to their children and grandchildren. The lump sum superannuation proposals do not just relate to airline pilots and rich businessmen. They relate to ordinary men and women of Australia who, during their working lives, have been prepared to take action to prepare for their retirements. They are being belted over the head. The message from the Hawke socialist Government is now clear-people should not prepare for their retirement, be prudent or endeavour to look after themselves: Big brother will do it for them.

The third blow was the freezing of the tax threshold. If ever a government stands condemned for doublespeak, Hawkespeak, cant and hypocrisy it is this Government. In fact, the Government during its term in opposition repeatedly plugged the question of the tax threshold and pointed out that unless the tax threshold was lifted more and more pensioners would fall into the situation of having to pay tax. As the result of this Government's actions thousands of Australian pensioners who currently are not paying tax will now have to pay tax because this Government has not moved up the tax threshold. The Government will probably catch anything betwen 25,000 and 50,000 Australian pensioners in the next financial year who will be told that while they have not had to pay tax in the past they will have to pay it in the future. Is this the way the Government treats old people? Is this the way it shows its care and concern for the elderly ? The mere delivery of a tax assessment of a few hundred dollars will place many of these people in a situation of absolute terror. Where will they get the money from? Where will they be able to find the assets to pay?

I now turn to the question of asset means testing. The former Prime Minister, the Rt Hon. Malcolm Fraser, following the humane and just lead of Prime Minister Whitlam, moved successfully in this Parliament in 1978 to abolish asset means testing, a move which was supported by many members of the Labor Party. I can tell honourable members the move was publicly applauded by members of the ALP in Tasmania. What has the Government now done? It is now bringing in legislation which will hang over the old people of Australia for the next 12 months. They will fret and worry as to what it is doing. Senator Grimes now says: 'Of course, we will consult with the pensioner groups'. I suggest he should have consulted with the pensioner groups before he announced this incredible legislation.

Under this legislation pensioners who put their money into jewellery or works of art will not be caught, but pensioners who have a small holiday shack at a coastal seaside resort bought for probably #2,000 or #3,000 40 years ago will find that that will be deemed to be an income producing asset and their pension will be docked. The plain fact of the matter is that Senator Grimes has conceded that the asset means test will affect over 300,000 pensioners, either in reduction of their existing pension or wiping it out completely. Does the Government think it is right that out there in the rest of Australia, in peoplesville, two million pensioners are wondering whether they will be caught up in this iniquitous asset means test. We should not pretend it will get only the tall poppies. What the Government is effectively doing-as the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) who spoke earlier in relation to farm properties pointed out-is hitting and punishing those who built up assets which they, in turn, wish to pass on to their family.

As to the Medicare mugging, the Government will effectively reduce the consumer price index by 2.6 per cent. That means that as of May next year when pensions will go up, single pensioners will be robbed by the present Hawke socialist Government of $2.30 a week-that will be a continuing weekly robbery of their pension-and married couples by $3.90 per week. Shame on the Government; it is not a caring government. It has betrayed the pensioners of Australia. Grey power sees what the Government is doing, grey power will remember and grey power will take it out on the Labor Government at the next Federal election when it will be turfed out of office, and properly so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) pointed out that the Opposition continues to misrepresent the facts. I will not say any more about what the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) had to say. I am sure the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) will deal with him in his summing up at the end of this debate. I would like to take the opportunity to congratulate the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) and his staff on doing a magnificent job in the formulation of the Budget Papers for the Department of Social Security. I also congratulate the departmental heads throughout Australia and the staff who work for the departmental heads and for the Department of Social Security. They do a marvellous job for me and all the Queensland Federal members and senators. I mention especially Mr Nolan, the Director in Queensland and Miss Terese Guilfoyle.

SPEECH.PARA: Members of the staff have a very difficult and complex job. They deal with many complex problems every day. I congratulate them on the way they handle the problems, especially for the aged, the infirm and the unemployed. I would be the last one to add to their work load, but I suggest that there is one area where they could do a little better than at present, and that is in regard to co- operating with the Australian Electoral Office. The estimates of expenditure for the Department of Administrative Services show that we are spending some $4,362, 000 for accommodation and installation of computer facilities for the Department of Social Security. Page 50 of the explanatory notes shows that the Department of Social Security is spending another $2,036,000. Page 30 mentions the spending of another $14,148,000. I think that is worth while. We need these extra Stratplan computer facilities to enable people to get their payments on time and to check on the fraudulent behaviour of people who are recipients of social security payments. I will deal with that point later on.

I point out that we are spending many millions of dollars in updating the computer systems for the Department of Social Security. I thought this would be a very good time to update the system. With the technology we have today the Department of Social Security would be able to assist the Australian Electoral Office. I have written letters in this regard. I pointed out to the Special Minister of State (Mr Beazley) and the Minister for Social Security that it had been brought to my attention that many people who contact my electoral office and are benefit or pension recipients are not on the electoral roll. I always check the people who come into my office. If they want me to give them assistance and check with the Department of Social security. I always make sure that they are registered. If they are not I try to help them. If they are over 18 years of age and are Australian citizens we always try to make sure they get on the roll. It is mandatory that an Australian citizen who is over the age of 18 and has lived in a certain residence for a certain period be registered. He can get fined if he is not. These people can be paid unemployment benefits or social security benefits and they do not have to be on the roll. I thought we could work out a system where the Department of Social Security and the Australian Electoral Office would be able to work in co-operation with one another.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good idea.

—I think it is a very good idea, as the honourable member points out. On page 49 of the explanatory notes we find that the Department of Social Security has to pay the Australian Electoral Office for the cost of microfiche access to the Electoral Office records. In 1982 the expenditure amounted to $10, 840; it has increased now to $98,000. I would like the Minister to explain how the increase occurred. Perhaps the Department of Social Security will take on board what I have suggested. A Press release from the Australian Electoral Office written by the Chief Electoral Officer dated 26 September 1983 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Electoral office research reveals massive underenrolment of more than 500,000 . . . amongst young unemployed.

Surely, those people would be receiving social security payments. Yet we find that 500,000 people are not on the roll. Surely we could work out a way in which the Department of Social Security can work in co-operation with the Australian Electoral Office because we do pay these people an amount of money. The Minister for Social Security replied to my letter. He pointed out that he appreciated the rationale behind my suggestion, and pointed out a few of the problems that existed within his Department. The Special Minister of State also appreciated what I was saying. He said in the letter-I will not read the letter out-that he would appreciate a little more co-operation from the Department of Social Security. Perhaps we can get the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, who is at the table, to encourage Senator Grimes to take that matter on board. This would help to get these young people on the roll. The Press statement of the Australian Electoral Office stated that the young people do not know enough about this matter. The Department of the Special Minister of State will be spending $3m to encourage people to get on the roll. Surely we could be spending that money in co-operation with the Department of Social Security in creating jobs instead of advertising and giving it to the media barons, although, hopefully, that would be successful, but I do not believe it would be. The Press release states:
Many people believe that . . . the Government will do that job for them . . .

I think we should do the job for them. This is reflected in the Press release. Young people will get on the roll if the Government helps them. That is a good point to make. I believe that this would stop a lot of fraud in the Social Security Department. We know that there are rogues who have three addresses. We see from the explanatory notes for the Department of Social Security that the Department checks the electoral roll to ensure that people are not defrauding it .

Let us look at the figures. The payout from the Department of Social Security this year will be $16 billion. In 1982-83, some 12,661 incidents of fraudulent negotiations were detected. If that was the number that was detected, one can imagine the numbers that are not being caught up with. I believe that, if the Ministers do as I suggest, we will catch many more of these people. The other day a bank manager in Brisbane told me that people have come into the bank with their pay cheque in one hand and a social security unemployment cheque in the other and have cashed both cheques at the one time. So it is going on. These are the people with whom we could probably catch up if we were, in co-operation with the Australian Electoral Office, to make more checks and to make sure that recipients of the dole are over 18 years of age and Australian citizens. If so, they should be on the electoral roll. I hope the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs will talk to the Department of Social Security and encourage the Minister for Social Security to take further steps to ensure that what I have been suggesting takes place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As this debate involves the Department of Social Security and the Department of Health, I wish to address myself to two specific concerns: First, the assets test; and secondly, the affect of Medicare on bush nursing hospitals. I speak on these two matters because the Labor Government's decisions in both these areas show a total absence of prior consultation with interested bodies as well as revealing a very dangerous philosophical approach. I shall examine first the Government's failure to consult relevant bodies, interested persons and the community in regard to the assets tests on eligibility for pensions. I say to the Committee as, no doubt, could other honourable members, that when the announcement was made in the Budget on 23 August a great many pensioners in a terrified state approached my electoral office. They were confused, scared and, quite simply, terrified, of what the future would bring. It is encumbent upon any government, when it makes a decision such as this-a quite radical decision-to consult properly, to inform properly and to prepare the way before announcing it. I and my colleagues say that this Government has failed to do that. It stands condemned for causing a great deal of fear to a great many people.

SPEECH.PARA: The absurdity of the assets test has already been covered by the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) and the honourable member for Dennison (Mr Hodgman) . I simply say that the stupidity of the assets test can be no better highlighted than by the illustration that a person can receive a pension so long as his capital is invested in one home, one car and antique jewellery or furniture. I can certainly cite examples from my electorate office files of pensioners who have approached me who have one very humble home and possibly at the same time another very humble home, both of very little value. They let the second home or permit their children or relatives to live in it rent free or at a subsidised rent. The situation, which needs to be clarified by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes), is that such a person will have his or her pension reduced or, in some circumstances, denied. That is clearly unjust and discriminatory.

I now turn to the Government's lack of consultation in regard to Medicare and bush nursing hospitals. The decisions made in regard to bush nursing hospitals have been of substantial concern to local communities as well as those who work within those hospitals. Again, this Government failed to consult properly or to take advice from the Victorian Bush Nursing Association. Indeed, I am led to understand that the Minister's Department had actually misplaced the submission from the Association. That would be a quite intolerable act of incompetence. The fact that the Minister did not properly consider that submission is reflected in the Medicare legislation. Under that legislation, as most honourable members would realise, any person who wishes to attend a bush nursing hospital and who also wants to avoid high public hospital costs will have to take out private health insurance in addition to the compulsory one per cent levy on his income.

The question for bush nursing hospitals is simply this: Will people in rural communities who are unable to travel long distances to public hospitals be able to afford to take out private health insurance as well as paying the one per cent Medicare levy? The answer to that, I suspect, is no. Therefore, the very survival of numerous bush nursing hospitals is at stake. Did this Government properly consult those affected? Did it consult local councils, general practitioners or the Bush Nursing Association? The answer is no. Again, the Government stands condemned for introducing very serious discriminatory legislation without prior and proper consultation.

I wish now to address myself to the philo- sophical implications of the Government's action in regard to bush nursing hospitals and Medicare as well as the assets test. I certainly believe, together with my colleagues, that the Government's philosophical approach in these areas has been demonstrated unmistakably to hit at the diligent person, the provident person, who seeks to care for himself and to prepare for his future. It seeks to implement a form of socialism which makes a person dependent on the state to an unnecessary degree. We must consider in addition to those two areas the Government's superannuation decisions and its attacks on the non-government schools. It boils down to simply this: This Government has no understanding-it deliberately has no understanding- of free enterprise and people who seek to care for themselves, to educate their children, to meet their health needs and to prepare for their retirement. This Government is hitting at some very basic foundations of our society. It will reap the anger of the people as the people reject this form of conformity, this brand of socialism.

The Opposition stands for a person's right to prepare for his own future, his own retirement and, in whichever part of the country he may live, to receive the appropriate services. The Government has no empathy with people of rural communities, as evidenced by the fact that bush nursing hospitals in numerous rural communities will have to close. That will throw a large number of people out of work and will cause great inconvenience to, as well as create great costs for, people and families who have to travel distances to public hospitals. It is a surprise to me as well as to my National Party and Liberal Party colleagues that those Government members who have bush nursing hospitals within their electorates are silent on this issue. It is quite impossible for honourable members such as the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) to argue that bush nursing hospitals are satisfied with these arrangements. They simply are not, because their very survival is threatened. The Opposition stands for the paramount importance of the individual and his right to determine his life and to prepare properly for his family and for the future.

In conclusion, I wish to raise a point which the honourable member for Murray raised and on which he was challenged by the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Free). The honourable member for Macquarie stated that he is in favour of the assets test. He said that it will be great for pensioners because pensioners can invest their money at 14 per cent but be calculated at only 10 per cent. This needs to be clarified. What the honourable member for Macquarie failed to take into account is that the Government is claiming that the inflation rate will fall dramatically and that consequently interest rates will also fall below 10 per cent. What then of the pensioner who will receive 8 per cent interest but is calculated at 10 per cent?

TALK.START.PARA: —The argument is not so hot then.

—As the honourable member for Murray says, the argument of the honourable member for Macquarie falls down around him. It is simply inaccurate and misleading. I ask the Minister to clarify that point if he is at all able to do so. I very much doubt that he is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wells Mr D.McM.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to take more than a minute or two of the time of the Committee, nor do I think the Committee would wish me to do so. I refer to some remarks made much earlier in this debate by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) who referred to the removal from the national health free list of two milk substitutes, pregestimil and glucose nutramigen. The honourable member for Mackellar suggested that the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) was ill advised when he took this action. I would like to set the record straight on that matter. Bristol Myers Co. Pty Ltd, the company responsible for producing the two milk substitutes pregestimil and glucose nutramigen, which milk substitutes are for babies allergic to ordinary milk, increased the cost of those two products by 59 per cent and 54.7 per cent respectively. This company expected that cost increase to be met by the Australian taxpayers by a direct subsidy through the national health scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister was placed in a rather invidious situation. Either he had to accept the situation and allow the Australian taxpayers to subsidise this extra amount or he had to make a stand at that point and say that that was not going to happen. No Australian Minister for Health could reasonably stand back and allow every multinational pharmaceutical corporation which wished, without any notice, to increase the prices of its products by 59 per cent or 54 per cent to do so. If every pharmaceutical company did that, the cost to the Australian taxpayer would be an extra $200m a year. The Australian Government cannot stand back and allow itself to be blackmailed by multinational pharmaceutical corporations.

Many people have come to my office to complain about what has happened, and I have explained the situation to them. Many people in my electorate have been affected by this situation. I have suggested to those people that they contact the pharmaceutical corporation directly, and it would be surprising if that company were not prepared to make some allowances for people in genuine need who have suffered as a result of its cost increases. I have been told that the Minister is perfectly happy to talk about any reasonable proposal if the company wishes to talk with the Minister. It just has to come back with a reasonable proposal. What it cannot do to the Australian taxpayers is increase the cost of its products by 59 per cent or 54 per cent and expect the Australian taxpayers simply to cop it. What we need is some indication of its cost of production, for example, that the cost of manufacture has gone up.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has had it for three years. The company has been giving it for three years. You are talking nonsense.

—The honourable member for Mackellar suggests that the company has been giving that sort of information for three years. The latest information I have received is that the cost of manufacture has gone down. I am willing to be corrected on that subject. If the honourable member for Mackellar would like to produce some statistics, that would be useful. But my information is that they are making this increase at a time their production costs have actually declined . We are saying that any reasonable proposal the company wishes to come back with will be looked at. In the meantime, while we realise that many Australians are being seriously inconvenienced by this action, the action was forced by the company, and it is up to the company to come back with a reasonable proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dobie The Hon J.D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. I will not fall into the temptation of answering the comments made by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Wells (Mr Petrie). From my scant current knowledge, I doubt that his figures are right. Some of us in this Parliament have been faced for a very long time with the problem of children who cannot use cows' milk. I suggest to the previous speaker that he go back to his books and look at some of the facts. I was very pleased to hear the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) refuting him and saying something along these lines.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to raise only two matters in the time alloted to me in this debate. First of all, the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Free) quoted the NSW Building Society as saying that the assets test was not sinister or unreasonable , that it was overcoming exploitation of the system and that only a small percentage of people would be worse off. That may well be the eventual situation , but at present the problem is that never before has a government caused such complete distress amongst the elderly in the community because of the uncertainty and confusion it has placed in their minds. As someone who has been very involved with social security matters for the past 20 years, not the last six months, let me assure honourable members that I have never seen as many people come to my Caringbah office in Sydney totally concerned, totally confused and, as a result, totally worried.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the same all over Australia.
—I agree with that.
—And in McPherson.

—I am sure that McPherson is having the same problem, although I expect it is not quite the same as my area. Unlike some previous speakers, I do not single out the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes), but the Hawke Labor Government. In its approach to social security, it has singled out-this has to be repeated over and over again-a section of the community which is not capable of changing its incomes, its assets or its lifestyles. These people are in a state of sheer confusion. 'Should we sell the house to our children or should we put money from our bank account into our grandchildren's names?' These things are being said not by very wealthy people who drive limousines and big cars but by the ordinary people in my electorate, those wise people who voted me here in March of this year. They come to me complaining that they do not know which way to turn. What do I say to these dear people? I say: 'Please do not change your asset holdings. Please do not get panicked by this Government. Please do not believe that this Government knows what it is about because it does not'. The Government brought in the appropriations that we are now debating and then said: 'We will do this, we will help these people'.

SPEECH.PARA: There are some aspects of the Budget of this Government of which I do approve. I am very pleased that the Minister has shown great initiative in the areas of disability and rehabilitation. His wish to get rehabilitation patients involved in the administration of their own affairs is a very good and forward looking move. I congratulate him for that, but that is about the only thing I can congratulate him for when I see the concern that he is causing to the elderly. That applies to not just the elderly but also to the frail who are not elderly. It applies to the infirm. It applies to the ill. It applies to those who are dependent on pensions of any description. The younger a pensioner, the more distressing this becomes. I criticise the Government roundly for having brought in an assets test which will not be promulgated for a year. During that year we will hear people ask whether the beach house will be ignored in the assets test, as the caravan is now ignored. How many people live in caravans when they retire ? Not too many.

The measures that the Minister has introduced have no sanity, sense or logic. With regard to this lack of logic, I sincerely hope that the Minister is not being confused by the advice from his departmental officers. I hope this lack of logic is soon cleared up. The Government is playing with people's emotions and not with social justice, which is what it should be trying to introduce. I will pardon the Minister this year because it is his first year as a Minister. But I hope he makes some quick decisions and does not rely on spending his money, as the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) quickly pointed out, in increasing the public relations section of his Department. We cannot blame the Minister for this because every department in the Government has increased its public relations expenditure. How marvellous this is! Have they done so because it will take such an extra effort to stop people from being confused? I suspect that, if the Government implements public relations campaigns as it has implemented its policy statements, there will be more confusion in every honourable member's electorate in this country. I know of the personal concern of some of the Government members who have spoken in this debate. They will find themselves faced with this problem. I say in all fairness to the honourable member for Macquarie that he may regret having said in the House today that there is nothing sinsiter or unreasonable in the Government's policy. The point to be borne in mind is that all his constituents in Macquarie are totally and utterly confused and quite devastated.

TALK.START.PARA: —They understand it.
—It may be the mountain air. But to use a word, it is one of the obscenities of politics and it should be understood as such.
—Ha, ha!

—The honourable member giggles. Perhaps he should bear in mind that this is not a giggling matter. I conclude by saying that I agree with the remarks of my counterpart and friend, the honourable member for Griffith (Mr Humphreys), the Government Whip. I, too, pay tribute to the Department of Social Security staff in my electorate. I pay tribute to the staff of the Caringbah branch, who refused to go on strike when strike action was taken. They did not refuse because they disagreed with the issue of the strike, but because they believed, and said so publicly in my area, that they were more concerned that it would interfere with the people whom they had to deal with. I pay tribute to their humanity and to their deep concern. My secretary, Mrs Ridoutt, and Mr Thomas and his staff have a close relationship.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter that the honourable member for Griffith discussed was fraud. We all know it can happen. We know people are guilty of doing it. Proving it, as we saw in the Greek conspiracy case, is impossible. When these matters are pursued, it becomes unfair to some people. I caution the Government to be careful in its investigations in this regard. But I encourage it, to use the positive words that the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) dared use, to move into the field of identity cards. In this age of high technology we require proof of identity for almost every second thing that we do. People need an identity card to enter this building. As members of parliament, we need an identity card to enter any government building in this city. Whenever we, as individuals, enter any defence establishment, even thought we are members of the highest forum in the country, we still require an identity card. I believe that in order to solve this grass roots problem of identity, we should bring in an identity card system. It will in one fell swoop help to resolve, if not the problem of unemployment, the constant accusations that are made against the unemployed. I do not believe that as much fraud exists as one would think. If we had introduced an identity card system some years ago, when I tried-I regret to say unsuccessfully-to persuade the previous Government to introduce an identity card system, it would have cost $8m. I suspect it would now cost $10m. But it would be far better spend than that spent on public relations sections. As I say , I grieve for the people in my electorate who are having sleepless nights-this is the truth; it is not political rhetoric-because of the confusion that the present Minister has caused with his Budget statements.
